Open-Ended Response

One suggestion I would like to share relates to the “Supportive” core value and how we continue supporting employees as the company grows. Increasing vacation days- especially for long-tenured employees- would help reinforce a positive, healthy work environment and demonstrate appreciation for ongoing commitment. After six years with Rocscience, I would truly value additional vacation time as part of feeling supported and recognized as the company continues to expand.

column47: The new sales team (predominately male, new hires) is based on a commission structure. Therefore, there is no incentive for the team to help each other out other than as a kind gesture. However, since there is no existing relationship, there is no good relationship to maintain. We are experiencing our largest quarter ever, and there has been difficulty coping with increased inquiries, training new hires, increased pressure to track down overdue payments, increased demand for record keeping in salesforce (I agree that this is important but it has not be executed in a way that is time effective for sales-people), and process orders.    Middle management has always been supportive, but it seems the expectations from senior management continue to grow with no plan to monitor workload from administrative tasks while trying to achieve target.    It would be beneficial if the admin work (processing orders, and tracking down payments for closed opportunities, etc.) was removed so we can focus on revenue.
column48: I feel that the recent changes across the company may have made it harder for the rollout of our core values to really stand out. It also seems like many people have had a heavier workload over the past few months and are, understandably, focused on keeping things moving.
column49: No challenges with new acquisitions since I am not on the software side.
column50: I’ve been asking for help over the past six months on whether there might be any opportunities for my husband at Rocscience. I understand these things can take time, but I’m feeling discouraged that I haven’t received any updates, especially given the recent increase in new hires, including some referred candidates.    If it’s not possible at this time, I completely understand - I just value clear communication. Going so long without any response has been difficult, and I wanted to share how this has affected me.

column49: Although we acquire new companies, it can feel scope of personal growth is not much. There is no clear way of advancement within the corporate structure.     Given we are doing our best to contribute towards company's future:  -What is next for me?   -What goals do I need to meet for next promotion?  -What is the next promotion in the first place?  -With promotion do I get better PIUs or salary bump?     Rocscience is a phenomenal place to work. With these questions answered and a clear path of advancement it will be even better.

column47: Our company's management is incapable of communicating clearly, and seems to have total contempt for our customers. I would consider these to be significant barriers to applying our core values.
column48: Since these values were introduced, it has become clear that our main responsibility is no longer towards our customers, but rather towards our investors. I'm not saying that the core values are the cause of this change - I'm  just pointing out that this change has taken place.
column49: I may be wrong, but so far as I can tell, the company has not made any meaningful attempts to integrate the new acquisitions in the last several months.
column50: Plenty of people at Rocscience were aligned with these values before they'd ever been codified. Those people are continuing to embody these values today.    I have no objections to the core values in and of themselves. What I object to is the way they are being used - namely, as a marketing tool. So far as I can see, these core values are being wielded for three purposes: to impress our investors, to attract new hires, and (maybe?) to entice potential future buyers. It's a shame to see perfectly honourable values misused in this way.

column49: I would like to get a better understanding of how us acquiring these new companies is benefiting them, us, as well as our customers.
column50: Our core values weren’t meant to change who we are — they were meant to capture and communicate what has always made us who we are.    If this isn't the case, then maybe it should be. I think some of the questions in the survey may have been focusing on trying to observe change in the company's behavior since the introduction of the values. Rocscience had excellent implicit core values to begin with. It's hard to write down guiding values for a culture since it's a complex and evolving thing. I believe that writing them down should be an attempt to highlight what makes us special and what we have always done to serve as a guiding light, but I wouldn't expect it to change our behavior much, especially since Rocscience has been living these principles for many years, and our culture as a whole is much more nuanced than just 5 values. That said, I appreciate that reflecting on these values can still help us see where we can continue to grow and strengthen our culture.

column47: Limited onboarding and integration beyond day one make it harder for new hires to fully understand how things work, who does what, and how our values show up in practice.    Communication can feel fragmented at times, with information shared through different channels and not always reaching everyone clearly or consistently.
column50: The values themselves are strong and directionally aligned with how a modern software company should operate. The gap is less in the wording and more in consistent reinforcement: clearer onboarding, more deliberate communication, simple agile habits (planning, review, feedback loops), and more visible cross-team interaction would help translate the values from posters and slides into everyday behaviour.

column47: Many people are comfortable hence resistant to support values like innovation.     Then, the company needs clear coordinators that create bridges between the teams, which doesn't exist right now.  Because it's hard to understand how to support each other when we don't have a cohesive plan and clear communication across teams.

column50: With all of the new internal hires, I feel that management doesn't necessarily see "excellence" in our current teams because people have been hired and given high-level titles from outside the company, while our internal talent was not necessarily considered. I would have liked to see management invest in the growth of our existing team members instead of hiring people outside of the company. This signals a lack of trust in our existing talent. Sometimes it feels like new employees are valued more than those who have been around for many years.

column47: Overall, our team applies our core values consistently, with only minor challenges from occasional time pressures.

There are a lot of moving pieces, which can make it challenging to clearly understand priorities, ownership, or how decisions align with our core values. When communication or direction isn’t fully clear, it can be difficult to stay consistent in how the values are applied day-to-day.
